I learned a great deal about several different schools of thought in western philosophy, beginning with Cartesian Skepticism and Dualism and ending in the final week with Kantian metaphysics. The course is broadly focused on metaphysics and epistemology, not on logic or ethics; some mentions of Kantian and Humean ethics were mentioned, but only in passing. The course is first and foremost and introductory class in philosophy. That means that almost all of the work you will be doing in the course will be either evaluative or comparative (the two essays, of the form "Explain what X says about Y in book Z, and evaluate their argument", or "Compare the thoughts of A and B on topic C"), while the final examination is merely descriptive ("What does G have to say about H"). Section is spent mostly reviewing the ideas covered in lecture to ensure the students have a good understanding of the material. You will be expected to "read" a passage or two a week; I put "read" in quotation marks not because I think you ought to not do the readings (you really should) but because it is not necessary to do well in the course if you don't, provided you have a good understanding of what the readings actually say. Again, I strongly encourage you to actually do the readings (it's really not that much, you can find the time).

Strengths: Michael Della Rocca is a great person to teach this course. He has a very good command of the material at hand and he is very good at making the lectures interesting (no small feat when covering Spinoza for first year students). The material itself is interesting enough. The workload was exceedingly manageable (only two essays plus the final), bordering on "Too Easy," but I doubt many will find fault in that. The readings were a good selection of many different philosophers, and the broad themes covered in the course were essential.

Weaknesses: I feel that this class, in attempting to be accessible to first-year students or non-majors, perhaps spends too much time focusing on "What did philosopher X say about Y?" and too little time focusing on "Is Y a good theory? What can we say about it?" There was very little "philosophizing" done in this course, which was kind of disappointing. For a concrete example, I wish we had spent more time discussing whether Cartesian Dualism was a good theory of the mind rather than just trying to learn what Descartes said about the mind-body problem. Due to the nature of the course, section was far more exegetic than I would have liked. Additionally, I feel that some ideas were covered far too briefly, while some ideas were given too much consideration. It's impossible to cover Kantian metaphysics in a single week, and we only actually read the Introduction to Critique of Pure Reason rather than any of the actual material. Admittedly, this is a really hard text, but I would have preferred to see us spend a bit more time covering the main ideas and debating them.

I would probably not recommend this course. First, if you want a relatively easy way to get an A, don't take this course; there are many easier courses to take for a good grade. There are only 3 major assessments in this course (2 papers and 1 exam), and if you do badly on any single one of them, you will be unable to recover your grade. Second, this course is also badly structured for learning philosophical writing and thinking. The TA's did not offer very thorough feedback on the papers, and it was incredibly difficult to gauge how they were evaluated. Remember, this is a content on philosophical content, not on how to actually learn what philosophy is about. On the bright side of things, the workload is incredibly low. While there are assigned readings, you don't actually have to do most of them in order to do well in the course, as philosophy papers have to do far more with arguments and evaluation as opposed to textual citation.

Whether or not you should take this course (assuming it isn't a requirement for you) is a difficult question. I think it has a lot of things going for it; in no particular order, (1) it's pretty easy. Two essays which have an assortment of prompts to choose from and which are graded pretty generously. Minimal readings. If you are comfortable with you ability to write a philosophy paper quickly, this could be a really easy A for you. (2) The professor and TFs are great. MDR is an absolute legend and you should definitely try to take a course with him. He really makes the work come to life and it's a pleasure to go to class every week. 

That being said, there are good reasons not to take it: (a) there are other classes that cover the same material, or parts of it, better. Want to learn about Kant? Take a class in Kantianism, or take PHIL 175 (Ethics with Kagan). Want to learn about Metaphysics? Take a metaphysics course. This course is definitely geared towards introductory students, which means that if you're already familiar with philosophy in general, it can be kind of dull. (b) Honestly, I'm not a fan of most metaphysics. I would really love to have an honest debate about whether or not some of these ideas are rigorous or what the problems they have are. If you don't enjoy metaphysics, look elsewhere.

Overall, I'm glad I took the course. It was interesting enough, had a great teacher and TF, came with a chill workload and final, and it padded by grades nicely.
